title: Friday, 20th October, 2017

Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 199.00, down 13 (-6.13%), High: 218.20, Low: 195.00, Volume: 3.62m
PM11:15am

q3s predictably dreadful

11:15 am
PM11:15am

https://www.invest...171020070000P913A/

PM11:15am

Company grinding to a halt, as planned

PM11:16am

Talks between Barrick and Tanzania underway -- but there's no solid news of a resolution

11:16 am
PM11:16am

https://www.invest...171020070000P0161/

PM11:16am

Let me get Shore to talk us through it

PM11:17am

Acacia Mining’s Q3 results provide a stark illustration of the impact of the Tanzanian Government’s ban on mineral concentrate exports as revenues fell by 40% to $170.6m (Q3 2016 US$284.7m) and EBITDA dropped by 60% to US$50.3m (Q3 2016 - US$124.8m). On a year to date basis, revenue declined by 29% to US$562.3m and EBITDA by 32% to US$309.7m.
Capital expenditure has been cut drastically to US$35.6m for the quarter (Q3 2016 – US$52.9m) but even so cash balances fell to US$95.3m (Q3 2016 – US$302.1m) and net cash fell to US$24.3m (Q3 b2016 – US$202.7m).

11:17 am
PM11:17am

The company points to the remedial measures it has implemented in response to the measures, which are exacerbated by the “lack of refunds of VAT”, including:
Alterations to the process flowsheet at the Buzwagi mine to focus exclusively on dore gold production at the expense of concentrates
The reduction in operations at the Bulyanhulu mine “with all underground mining and the processing of underground ore having ceased”
Purchase of put options to secure a minimum US$1300/oz gold price “for the majority of our gold sales until February 2018”

PM11:17am

Oh, I hadnt seen -- they are losing their COO

PM11:18am

Mark Morcombe

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Not very loyal of him -- but maybe there's an explanation

PM11:18am

Back to Shore

PM11:19am

The company reiterates its revised production and cost guidance of 750,000 ounces of gold at an all-in-sustaining cost of US$880-920/oz.
Acacia’s 63.9% owner, Barrick Gold has announced a proposal to create a new Tanzanian operating company “to manage Bulyanhulu, Buzwagi and North Mara, and all future operations in the country.” The new company is intended to ensure that “the economic benefits generated by Acacia’s operations would be shared with Tanzania on a 50/50 basis going forward.“ In addition, Barrick has stated that in an effort to resolve the continuing tax claims in Tanzania, “Acacia will make a payment of $300 million to the Government of Tanzania”.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

The discussions between Barrick and the Tanzanian Government appear to have sidelined Acacia Mining which comments that “No formal proposal has been put to Acacia for consideration at this point in time. As stated at the press conference, any proposal agreed in principle between Barrick and the GoT will require Acacia’s approval. Acacia will consider any proposal once it receives the full details and a further update will be provided when appropriate.”

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Talking about flow -- MOST are doing the crystal ball thing this morning

PM11:25am

Saying £330bn of new money gonna flow into UK equities by 2025

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:25 am
PM11:26am

We estimate up to £330bn will flow into equities by 2025 as auto enrolment (pensions) in the UK accelerates workplace DC pension growth and significantly favours greater equity allocations. Lessons from Australia suggest support for equity valuations.

PM11:26am

The growth in workplace DC pensions is one of the biggest opportunities in UK insurance & asset management with assets set to triple from 2015 to nearly £1trn by 2025

PM11:26am

Our analysis suggests equities and alternatives will be the biggest beneficiaries of this flow. Of the third of the UK working population captured by auto-enrolment, less than ~10% choose an allocation outside the default fund option. These default funds have an average equity allocation of 65% vs. overall UK pensions weighting of 47% (DB and DC combined). Within DC pensions, we expect assets allocated to alternatives to triple to ~£150bn by 2025, making them the biggest beneficiary.

~£330bn of gross flows to equities or ~4% of MSCI Europe (Market cap ~£7trn) by 2025. We model ~£530bn of flows into DC pensions 2017-2025 (~26% of this comes from auto-enrolment). We believe this will drive ~£330bn of inflows into equities, which is equivalent to ~4% of the current MSCI EU equity market capitalisation. Taking into account domestic allocations, ~25% of this could flow into the UK (~4% of the UK equity market capitalisation).

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Readacross from Australia. The introduction of superannuation and step up in guarantee rates over 1995-2003 saw equity allocations rise from 43% to 53%. We believe 23% of the industry is invested in Australian equities (~19% of ASX market capitalisation). When contribution rates doubled in 1995-2003, the P/E valuation of the ASX market was supported whilst global markets experienced a relative de-rating. The deep pool of capital likely buffered shocks and explains some of the relative premium multiples of Australian stocks.

Institutional investors have been structural sellers of UK equities for last 20 years. In the context of the UK market's capitalisation of over £2trn, ~£10bn new inflows into UK stocks provides a boost of around 0.5% p.a. We think the allocation of flows to domestic equity markets will be a constant and cumulative effect every year going forward and should provide greater support.

PM11:27am

Last bit

PM11:28am

Who is best placed? Asset managers with outsized exposure to UK and institutional clients, e.g. Schroders, alongside large workplace DC providers, like Aviva, Legal & General and M&G are better positioned. Partners Group is well positioned to benefit from rising alternatives AUM and large institutional clients.

PM11:37am

What else?

11:37 am
PM11:37am

There's bound to be loads of ECB discussion next week

PM11:37am

So here's a few cheat pars from UBS

PM11:37am

ECB to cut monthly purchases to €30bn, with a commitment for 9 months
We expect the ECB to announce next week (26 October) that it will cut its monthly asset purchases from €60bn to €30bn as of January, with a commitment for nine months, i.e. until end-September 2018. We think the ECB will leave open whether it will extend QE after September and hint that this decision will be taken in a data-dependent fashion, closer to the time. We believe the ECB will maintain a QE easing bias, indicating that it will stand ready to scale up QE again in the event of negative shocks. The ECB will likely reiterate that, in addition to the monthly asset purchases, maturing securities of its QE portfolio will be reinvested for the foreseeable future, and stress their quantitative significance. As part of its interest rate forward guidance, the ECB is likely to reiterate that key interest rates are likely to stay at current levels "for an extended period of time, and well past" the end of QE. We think the Bank will once again commit to maintaining a "very substantial degree of monetary accommodation" in order to bring inflation back to the target.

11:37 am
PM11:38am

QE to end after Q3-2018, first rate hikes as of 2019, liquidity to stay abundant
According to our base case scenario, the ECB will bring QE to a close by end-Sept, but we acknowledge the "risk" of a moderate QE extension during Q4 2018. In line with the ECB's guidance, we expect key interest rates to be hiked only after the end of QE, most likely as of 2019. Overall liquidity conditions are likely to stay accommodative. Our base case scenario for tapering (€30bn over 9 months) marks a change from our previous call, which centred on a stepwise reduction in QE over 6-9 months.

PM11:38am

Well, two

PM11:38am

Free money for a good while yet

11:44 am
PM11:44am

PM11:44am

Maybe right click and open in a separate tab

PM11:45am

UK takeovers have been rising since 2013, though are still well below the
pre global financial crisis level – The Brexit vote has not created a
meaningful change in activity levels. An activity bias to sub £5bn EV means
M&A remain a key theme in the UK small & mid cap space. UK M&A could
be supported by: (1) Weak Sterling; (2) Valuation discount of UK Small
Cap's relative to the US; (3) Strong balance sheets. On a sector basis the
TMT, industrial goods & services and consumer super sectors have seen the
larger proportion of activity over the last 15 years, but in recent years TMT
has seen the most activity and Consumer activity has been less prevalent.
We include a number of analyst comments on specific sectors.

PM11:55am

Avanti Communications Group plc (AIM: AVN) today announces that note holders holding in excess of 60% of the Company's outstanding notes have confirmed that they will consent (under a consent solicitation to be launched today) to certain amendments to the indentures governing those notes (the "Indentures"). These amendments will permit the Company to furnish its annual report for the year ended June 30, 2017 and its quarterly earnings release for the quarter ended September 30, 2017 by no later than January 31, 2018. The consents will also permit the Company to make certain changes to the call protection for a future tranche of an incremental facility which will be made under its existing Super Senior Facility.
